clusters.title: Guided by angels, pursued by chemtrails: the weird world of Florida health chief’s influential wife
clusters.neutral_headline: Guided by angels, pursued by chemtrails: the weird world of Florida health chief’s influential wife

items.title: Guided by angels, pursued by chemtrails: the weird world of Florida health chief’s influential wife
items.standfirst: Brianna Ladapo, the wife of Florida surgeon general Dr Joseph Ladapo, claims her husband won’t work with anyone she hasn’t vettedThe wife of Florida surgeon general Dr Joseph Ladapo, a leading vaccine skeptic, believes that angels have spoken to her and that “dark forces” are targeting her family with chemtrails, and has claimed her husband won’t work with anyone she hasn’t vetted.In published works and interviews reviewed by the Guardian, Brianna Ladapo – who edited her husband’s USA Today op-ed from March 2020 against Covid-19 shutdowns and appears alongside him at conferences – claims to have regularly received visions that come true and believes her life has been saved “multiple times” by angels. Continue reading...
items.content: Brianna Ladapo, the wife of Florida surgeon general Dr Joseph Ladapo, claims her husband won’t work with anyone she hasn’t vettedThe wife of Florida surgeon general Dr Joseph Ladapo, a leading vaccine skeptic, believes that angels have spoken to her and that “dark forces” are targeting her family with chemtrails, and has claimed her husband won’t work with anyone she hasn’t vetted.In published works and interviews reviewed by the Guardian, Brianna Ladapo – who edited her husband’s USA Today op-ed from March 2020 against Covid-19 shutdowns and appears alongside him at conferences – claims to have regularly received visions that come true and believes her life has been saved “multiple times” by angels. Continue reading...

She believes "dark forces" target her family with chemtrails.
Ladapo claims her husband only works with people she approves.
She edited her husband's op-ed against Covid-19 shutdowns.
Ladapo believes angels have saved her life multiple times.

clusters.title: Madness on a mountain: for 15 years, my mom was trapped in a mutual psychosis
clusters.neutral_headline: Madness on a mountain: for 15 years, my mom was trapped in a mutual psychosis

items.title: Madness on a mountain: for 15 years, my mom was trapped in a mutual psychosis
items.standfirst: She fell mysteriously ill while living in a remote cabin with my stepdad, and I suspected it was a cry for help. Then came the unexpected diagnosis: folie à deuxFor days before her last hospital visit, Mom’s texts worried me.She sent them from the one-room mountain cabin she shared with my stepfather, Mark. They pinged each day on my phone like tiny arrows: two dozen or more, with random all-caps.Mom: Making mark red velvet CAKE. we have the gang of coyotes eating and harassing down below on the flats. Going to rest and take it easy and go TOMORROW FOR FOOD and water AGAIN.Me: Make sure you’re hydrated!Mom: I will sweet ANGEL Continue reading...
items.content: She fell mysteriously ill while living in a remote cabin with my stepdad, and I suspected it was a cry for help. Then came the unexpected diagnosis: folie à deuxFor days before her last hospital visit, Mom’s texts worried me.She sent them from the one-room mountain cabin she shared with my stepfather, Mark. They pinged each day on my phone like tiny arrows: two dozen or more, with random all-caps.Mom: Making mark red velvet CAKE. we have the gang of coyotes eating and harassing down below on the flats. Going to rest and take it easy and go TOMORROW FOR FOOD and water AGAIN.Me: Make sure you’re hydrated!Mom: I will sweet ANGEL Continue reading...

ai_summary: A woman's mother fell ill while living in a remote cabin.
The mother and stepfather lived in a cabin in the mountains.
The daughter suspected her mother was sending a cry for help.
The mother was later diagnosed with folie à deux.
The article details the progression of the mother's illness.

clusters.title: Sainsbury’s recalls two own-brand hummus varieties over E coli fears

items.title: Sainsbury’s recalls two own-brand hummus varieties over E coli fears
items.standfirst: FSA says items could contain shiga toxin-producing Stec strain and have been recalled as a precautionSainsbury’s has recalled two varieties of its own-brand hummus over fears they may contain a deadly strain of E coli, advising customers who have bought the products not to eat them.The affected items are 315g containers of JS Classic Houmous, with a use-by date of 13 September, and 200g tubs of JS Lemon & Coriander Houmous with a use-by date of 14 September. Continue reading...
items.content: FSA says items could contain shiga toxin-producing Stec strain and have been recalled as a precautionSainsbury’s has recalled two varieties of its own-brand hummus over fears they may contain a deadly strain of E coli, advising customers who have bought the products not to eat them.The affected items are 315g containers of JS Classic Houmous, with a use-by date of 13 September, and 200g tubs of JS Lemon & Coriander Houmous with a use-by date of 14 September. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Sainsbury's recalled two hummus varieties due to E coli concerns.
The FSA warned that the products could contain a dangerous strain.
The affected products are JS Classic Houmous and JS Lemon & Coriander Houmous.
The recall is a precautionary measure to protect consumers.
Consumers are advised not to eat the recalled hummus.

clusters.title: ‘Extreme nausea’: Are EVs causing car sickness – and what can be done?
clusters.neutral_headline: ‘Extreme nausea’: Are EVs causing car sickness – and what can be done?

items.title: ‘Extreme nausea’: Are EVs causing car sickness – and what can be done?
items.standfirst: Phil Bellamy’s daughters refuse to ride in his electric car without travel sickness tablets. Are there other solutions?It was a year in to driving his daughter to school in his new electric vehicle that Phil Bellamy discovered she dreaded the 10-minute daily ride – it made her feel sick in a way no other car did.As the driver, Bellamy had no problems with the car but his teenage daughters struggled with sickness every time they entered the vehicle. Research has shown this is an issue – people who did not usually have motion sickness in a conventional car found that they did in EVs. Continue reading...
items.content: Phil Bellamy’s daughters refuse to ride in his electric car without travel sickness tablets. Are there other solutions?It was a year in to driving his daughter to school in his new electric vehicle that Phil Bellamy discovered she dreaded the 10-minute daily ride – it made her feel sick in a way no other car did.As the driver, Bellamy had no problems with the car but his teenage daughters struggled with sickness every time they entered the vehicle. Research has shown this is an issue – people who did not usually have motion sickness in a conventional car found that they did in EVs. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Some people experience car sickness in electric vehicles.
A driver's daughters refuse to ride in his EV without medication.
Research suggests motion sickness is more common in EVs.
The article explores potential causes of EV-related car sickness.
It investigates possible solutions to mitigate the problem.

clusters.title: Online misinformation putting women off contraceptive pill, study finds
clusters.neutral_headline: Online misinformation putting women off contraceptive pill, study finds

items.title: Online misinformation putting women off contraceptive pill, study finds
items.standfirst: Researchers say social media myths drive ‘nocebo effect’ of side-effects that are real but psychological in origin Social media misinformation about the contraceptive pill is encouraging women to view it so negatively that many give it up, a study has found.Researchers have identified myths spread on TikTok and other social media platforms as a key driver of users suffering side-effects that are real but psychological in origin. It is called the “nocebo effect”, the opposite of the better-known placebo effect.An expectation at the outset that the pill will be harmful.Low confidence in how medicines are developed.A belief that medicines are overused and harmful.A belief that they are sensitive to medicines. Continue reading...
items.content: Researchers say social media myths drive ‘nocebo effect’ of side-effects that are real but psychological in origin Social media misinformation about the contraceptive pill is encouraging women to view it so negatively that many give it up, a study has found.Researchers have identified myths spread on TikTok and other social media platforms as a key driver of users suffering side-effects that are real but psychological in origin. It is called the “nocebo effect”, the opposite of the better-known placebo effect.An expectation at the outset that the pill will be harmful.Low confidence in how medicines are developed.A belief that medicines are overused and harmful.A belief that they are sensitive to medicines. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Social media misinformation discourages women from using the pill.
Researchers identified myths on platforms like TikTok.
The myths contribute to the "nocebo effect" of side effects.
The nocebo effect causes psychological side effects.
The study highlights the impact of online information on health choices.

clusters.title: Trump can block Medicaid funds to ‘defund’ Planned Parenthood, court rules
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump can block Medicaid funds to ‘defund’ Planned Parenthood, court rules

items.title: Trump can block Medicaid funds to ‘defund’ Planned Parenthood, court rules
items.standfirst: Reproductive rights group condemns ruling as ‘backdoor abortion ban’ and says 200 US clinics may face closureThe Trump administration can move forward with its plan to “defund” Planned Parenthood by blocking it from receiving reimbursements from Medicaid, the US government’s insurance program for low-income people, a federal appeals court ruled late on Thursday.The ruling from the first US circuit court of appeals lifts a lower court’s preliminary injunction, which had stopped the Trump administration from enacting a provision of its tax and spending bill that axed Planned Parenthood’s ability to participate in Medicaid for one year. Continue reading...
items.content: Reproductive rights group condemns ruling as ‘backdoor abortion ban’ and says 200 US clinics may face closureThe Trump administration can move forward with its plan to “defund” Planned Parenthood by blocking it from receiving reimbursements from Medicaid, the US government’s insurance program for low-income people, a federal appeals court ruled late on Thursday.The ruling from the first US circuit court of appeals lifts a lower court’s preliminary injunction, which had stopped the Trump administration from enacting a provision of its tax and spending bill that axed Planned Parenthood’s ability to participate in Medicaid for one year. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A court ruled Trump can block Medicaid funds to Planned Parenthood.
The ruling allows the "defunding" plan to proceed.
The ruling came from a federal appeals court.
The reproductive rights group condemns the ruling.
The group says 200 clinics may face closure.

clusters.title: Has the meaning of life been within us all along? | Letters
clusters.neutral_headline: Article discusses the power of the unconscious mind

items.title: Has the meaning of life been within us all along? | Letters
items.standfirst: Readers respond to an article by Moya Sarner about the power of our unconscious minds to free ourselves and others from life in the shallows I was gladdened to read Moya Sarner’s reflections on a life enhanced by deeper meaning and more textured joy (A better life is possible – but only if you dive deep into your unconscious, 8 September). In a culture that too often celebrates relentless acquisition and action, her words offer timely encouragement towards another way of being.She observes: “We do to stay in the shallows, so we don’t have to be in the depths. But we know the way to a better life sits below the surface, not on it.” This image of the deep sea is an apt and illuminating metaphor for the hidden interior universe of currents and forces that shape us. Continue reading...
items.content: Readers respond to an article by Moya Sarner about the power of our unconscious minds to free ourselves and others from life in the shallows I was gladdened to read Moya Sarner’s reflections on a life enhanced by deeper meaning and more textured joy (A better life is possible – but only if you dive deep into your unconscious, 8 September). In a culture that too often celebrates relentless acquisition and action, her words offer timely encouragement towards another way of being.She observes: “We do to stay in the shallows, so we don’t have to be in the depths. But we know the way to a better life sits below the surface, not on it.” This image of the deep sea is an apt and illuminating metaphor for the hidden interior universe of currents and forces that shape us. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Article discusses the importance of deeper meaning and joy in life.
It suggests that a better life is found below the surface, not on it.
The article uses the deep sea as a metaphor for the hidden interior.
It encourages readers to explore the hidden forces that shape them.
The author believes that this exploration can lead to a better life.

clusters.title: What is ‘executive dysfunction’ and how do you overcome it?
clusters.neutral_headline: What is ‘executive dysfunction’ and how do you overcome it?

items.title: What is ‘executive dysfunction’ and how do you overcome it?
items.standfirst: Difficulty starting and getting overwhelmed by tasks are a few signs of it. We asked experts for tips on mitigating itTell us about your colorful wedding dressIn an ultra-viral TikTok video, a woman lies on her couch. “I’m tired. I should shower so it’ll wake me up; if I shower, I should exercise first so I don’t have to shower twice,” intones the voiceover. “If I’m going to exercise, I should eat first; if I’m going to cook, I should have coffee first so I have energy to cook,” it continues. The video – which has almost 5m views – bears the caption: “What executive dysfunction looks like.”Hundreds of videos have circulated through social media, pinning people’s various struggles on “executive dysfunction”. Each video follows similar themes: showing people failing to initiate tasks, growing overwhelmed by household chores or theorizing why they’re never on time. Continue reading...
items.content: Difficulty starting and getting overwhelmed by tasks are a few signs of it. We asked experts for tips on mitigating itTell us about your colorful wedding dressIn an ultra-viral TikTok video, a woman lies on her couch. “I’m tired. I should shower so it’ll wake me up; if I shower, I should exercise first so I don’t have to shower twice,” intones the voiceover. “If I’m going to exercise, I should eat first; if I’m going to cook, I should have coffee first so I have energy to cook,” it continues. The video – which has almost 5m views – bears the caption: “What executive dysfunction looks like.”Hundreds of videos have circulated through social media, pinning people’s various struggles on “executive dysfunction”. Each video follows similar themes: showing people failing to initiate tasks, growing overwhelmed by household chores or theorizing why they’re never on time. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The article explores the concept of "executive dysfunction".
It highlights difficulty starting and completing tasks as signs.
Experts offer tips on mitigating the effects of executive dysfunction.
Social media videos often depict struggles related to the condition.
The videos show people failing to initiate or complete tasks.

clusters.title: RFK Jr does not just reject vaccines. He rejects science and must step down | Bernie Sanders
clusters.neutral_headline: RFK Jr does not just reject vaccines. He rejects science and must step down

items.title: RFK Jr does not just reject vaccines. He rejects science and must step down | Bernie Sanders
items.standfirst: Kennedy is unfit to be our nation’s leading public health official because he rejects the fundamental principles of modern scienceSince taking office, Robert F Kennedy Jr, the secretary of the health and human services department (HHS), has undermined vaccines at every turn. He has dismissed the entire Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) vaccine advisory panel, narrowed access to life-saving Covid-19 vaccines, filled scientific advisory boards with conspiracy theorists and fired the newly appointed CDC director for refusing to rubber-stamp his actions.But his rejection of vaccines is only part of the problem. Secretary Kennedy is unfit to be our nation’s leading public health official because he rejects the fundamental principles of modern science. Continue reading...
items.content: Kennedy is unfit to be our nation’s leading public health official because he rejects the fundamental principles of modern scienceSince taking office, Robert F Kennedy Jr, the secretary of the health and human services department (HHS), has undermined vaccines at every turn. He has dismissed the entire Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) vaccine advisory panel, narrowed access to life-saving Covid-19 vaccines, filled scientific advisory boards with conspiracy theorists and fired the newly appointed CDC director for refusing to rubber-stamp his actions.But his rejection of vaccines is only part of the problem. Secretary Kennedy is unfit to be our nation’s leading public health official because he rejects the fundamental principles of modern science. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Robert F Kennedy Jr. has undermined vaccines since taking office.
He dismissed the CDC vaccine advisory panel and narrowed access.
Kennedy filled scientific boards with conspiracy theorists.
He fired the CDC director for not supporting his actions.
The author believes Kennedy rejects the principles of modern science.

clusters.title: What you need to know about Covid vaccines in the US this fall
clusters.neutral_headline: What you need to know about Covid vaccines in the US this fall

items.title: What you need to know about Covid vaccines in the US this fall
items.standfirst: In a move praised by RFK Jr, the FDA approved a new shot, but only for some people – here’s what to know about who can get them, and whereThere is a lot of confusion about Covid vaccines this year.In late August, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) announced that it had rescinded emergency use authorizations (a tool that allows the FDA to expedite the availability of certain medications) for Covid-19 vaccines. It also said it had approved updated versions of the Covid-19 vaccine, but only for certain groups. Continue reading...
items.content: In a move praised by RFK Jr, the FDA approved a new shot, but only for some people – here’s what to know about who can get them, and whereThere is a lot of confusion about Covid vaccines this year.In late August, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) announced that it had rescinded emergency use authorizations (a tool that allows the FDA to expedite the availability of certain medications) for Covid-19 vaccines. It also said it had approved updated versions of the Covid-19 vaccine, but only for certain groups. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The FDA approved updated Covid-19 vaccines in late August.
Emergency use authorizations for previous vaccines were rescinded.
Updated vaccines were approved for certain groups of people.
The article aims to clarify confusion surrounding the vaccines.
The FDA's actions have been praised by some individuals.

clusters.title: ‘I don’t know how we would survive’: caregivers speak of fears over upcoming Medicaid cuts
clusters.neutral_headline: ‘I don’t know how we would survive’: caregivers speak of fears over upcoming Medicaid cuts

items.title: ‘I don’t know how we would survive’: caregivers speak of fears over upcoming Medicaid cuts
items.standfirst: Program covers low-income families, but families brace for cuts to it as part of the Trump-backed ‘one big, beautiful bill’Whether taking care of an older parent, a relative with disabilities or a child with a serious medical condition, family caregivers in the US are nervous and afraid of upcoming cuts to Medicaid – including those resulting from the Donald Trump-backed legislation known as the One Big Beautiful Bill Act.The program, which serves low-income families, pregnant women, children, seniors and people with disabilities, enables more than 70 million people to receive critical services while alleviating some of the financial demands on caregivers. But now the bill could chip away at that support with cuts that include ending the temporary incentive for states to adopt the Medicaid expansion, implementing mandatory work requirements (with some exceptions), more frequent eligibility redeterminations for those covered under the Medicaid expansion, and reducing state funding that could force cuts to state-funded home and community-based services for older adults. Continue reading...
items.content: Program covers low-income families, but families brace for cuts to it as part of the Trump-backed ‘one big, beautiful bill’Whether taking care of an older parent, a relative with disabilities or a child with a serious medical condition, family caregivers in the US are nervous and afraid of upcoming cuts to Medicaid – including those resulting from the Donald Trump-backed legislation known as the One Big Beautiful Bill Act.The program, which serves low-income families, pregnant women, children, seniors and people with disabilities, enables more than 70 million people to receive critical services while alleviating some of the financial demands on caregivers. But now the bill could chip away at that support with cuts that include ending the temporary incentive for states to adopt the Medicaid expansion, implementing mandatory work requirements (with some exceptions), more frequent eligibility redeterminations for those covered under the Medicaid expansion, and reducing state funding that could force cuts to state-funded home and community-based services for older adults. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Caregivers in the US are worried about upcoming Medicaid cuts.
The cuts are part of the Trump-backed "One Big Beautiful Bill".
Medicaid serves low-income families, pregnant women, and others.
The bill could reduce support for over 70 million people.
Cuts include ending incentives and implementing work requirements.

clusters.title: It’s not too late: the House of Lords can still protect disabled people from this dangerous assisted dying bill | Lucy Webster
clusters.neutral_headline: It’s not too late: the House of Lords can still protect disabled people from this dangerous assisted dying bill

items.title: It’s not too late: the House of Lords can still protect disabled people from this dangerous assisted dying bill | Lucy Webster
items.standfirst: MPs passed it without sufficient safeguarding. If there is any point to the upper chamber, it is to give the legislation the open debate we needSign up for our new weekly newsletter Matters of Opinion, where our columnists and writers will reflect on what they’ve been debating, thinking about, reading and moreThe House of Lords has a rare opportunity to prove its worth to the country today, as it begins to debate the assisted dying bill. Personally, I would be in favour of peers throwing out the whole idea, which is what this dangerous and badly written bill surely deserves. But it is unlikely that they will want to go so directly against the Commons, especially on such a controversial issue. So instead I must hope that they listen to disabled people’s groups, as well as legal and medical experts, and at least undo some of the lower house’s most egregious errors.Whether you are for or against the principle of assisted dying (I am pro), we should be able to agree that the passage of this particular bill through the Commons has been haphazard, deeply unedifying and fundamentally flawed. The Lords should reject this precedent and, by adopting a better process, produce a much safer bill than the one they have been sent.Lucy Webster is a political journalist and the author of The View from Down Here: Life As a Young Disabled WomanDo you have an opinion on the issues raised in this article? If you would like to submit a response of up to 300 words by email to be considered for publication in our letters section, please click here. Continue reading...
items.content: MPs passed it without sufficient safeguarding. If there is any point to the upper chamber, it is to give the legislation the open debate we needSign up for our new weekly newsletter Matters of Opinion, where our columnists and writers will reflect on what they’ve been debating, thinking about, reading and moreThe House of Lords has a rare opportunity to prove its worth to the country today, as it begins to debate the assisted dying bill. Personally, I would be in favour of peers throwing out the whole idea, which is what this dangerous and badly written bill surely deserves. But it is unlikely that they will want to go so directly against the Commons, especially on such a controversial issue. So instead I must hope that they listen to disabled people’s groups, as well as legal and medical experts, and at least undo some of the lower house’s most egregious errors.Whether you are for or against the principle of assisted dying (I am pro), we should be able to agree that the passage of this particular bill through the Commons has been haphazard, deeply unedifying and fundamentally flawed. The Lords should reject this precedent and, by adopting a better process, produce a much safer bill than the one they have been sent.Lucy Webster is a political journalist and the author of The View from Down Here: Life As a Young Disabled WomanDo you have an opinion on the issues raised in this article? If you would like to submit a response of up to 300 words by email to be considered for publication in our letters section, please click here. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The House of Lords is debating the assisted dying bill.
The author hopes the Lords will address errors in the bill.
The author believes the bill's passage through the Commons was flawed.
The Lords should produce a safer bill than the one received.
The author is a political journalist and author of a book.

clusters.title: Children detained under Mental Health Act held for hours in A&E departments
clusters.neutral_headline: Children detained under Mental Health Act held for hours in A&E departments

items.title: Children detained under Mental Health Act held for hours in A&E departments
items.standfirst: Research finds children as young as nine in England and Wales taken to A&E because of lack of specialist suitesChildren as young as nine detained under the Mental Health Act are spending hours in NHS accident and emergency departments under police control rather than in specialist mental health assessment suites.The detention under the act of children in England and Wales in police cells was banned in 2017 but a lack of suitable options has led to the use of A&E departments. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

ai_summary: Children are spending hours in A&E under the Mental Health Act.
Research found children as young as nine are affected.
Police control children in A&E due to a lack of suites.
Detaining children in police cells was banned in 2017.
The lack of options has led to A&E department use.
